headline.main: A LONE TENANT'S VICTORY; The Cumberland's Conveniences Must Be Maintained for Him.

docs.lead_paragraph: An elevator service run solely for the accommodation of one man, a tenant of the sixth floor, in a dismantled Broadway apartment house, is something that will give Broadway food for thought. It is, however, only one of several services that must be maintained for this one tenant alone.

headline.main: Hotels and Resorts to Travel to in 2017

docs.lead_paragraph: Sometimes a hotel is just a place to sleep. Other times, it’s a destination.
docs.snippet: Sometimes a hotel is just a place to sleep. Other times, it’s a destination....

docs.lead_paragraph: At many large hotels, guest-room telephones come with small directories, listing what seem like dozens of numbers for hotel services. But in all North American Westin Hotels, guests can now dial just one number to order up almost anything the hotel offers. Telephone requests from guests go to a command center, where they are answered, then dispatched to the proper hotel staff member via radio units.

headline.main: After Guests Check In, the Rooms Check Out

docs.abstract: HI hotel in Nice, France, sports playful design by Matali Crasset; photo (Currents column) (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Matali Crasset, a Parisian who once worked for Philippe Starck, has herself become a design star known for bright colors and use of resin. Now Ms. Crasset, right, has done her first complete environment, the new 38-room HI hotel in Nice, France. Ms. Crasset said that the hotel offered ''a chance for people to try out living contemporary design.'' In the lobby, guests are encouraged to rearrange chairs and ottomans. A cage of birch plywood, left, surrounds the cafe and bar, where tables have removable laminated wooden tray tops and guests serve themselves. (There are no minibars in the rooms, only machines that dispense refreshments on each landing to encourage guests to get out and explore.) The rooms are based on nine concepts, including the indoor terrace room, above, where the furniture is arranged on a wooden deck in the center of the room. (There is an extra mattress beneath the bed in case a friend decides to stay over, free.) Only a row of leafy plants screen the shower from the bed. In the immaculate white-and-white room, the bathtub has a canopy and the bed is a mattress on a table.
docs.snippet: Matali Crasset, a Parisian who once worked for Philippe Starck, has herself become a design star known for bright colors and use of resin. Now Ms. Crasset, right, has done her first complete environment, the new 38-room HI hotel in Nice, France. M...

docs.lead_paragraph: Sofia Coppola's latest cinematic dreamscape, ''Somewhere'' (below), celebrates life at the Chateau Marmont, Hollywood's A-list stomping ground. But the film is by no means the first word on celebrity kerfuffles at the castle-esque hotel. It's where Elizabeth Taylor nursed Montgomery Clift back to health in Room 3F after his near-fatal car accident and, more recently, where Lindsay Lohan headed after one of her run-ins with the law. Here, a timeline of Chateau lore. 1929: Chateau Marmont opens as apartments.

docs.lead_paragraph: Bermuda's temperature-guarantee program provides a 10 percent refund on regular room rates on any day when, according to Bermuda's national weather service, the temperature fails to reach 68 degrees during January, February and March. (The discounts do not increase the colder it gets, so hoping for snow is pointless.) Twenty-six hotels participate in the program, which also provides passes for free bus and ferry transport as well as admission to Bermudan cultural attractions the day after any sub-68 day.

headline.main: Feeling the Burn in the Privacy of Your Room

docs.abstract: Christopher Elliott Practical Traveler column on hotels that are expanding their fitness offerings beyond workout rooms by offering room-service delivery of fitness equipment, exercise manuals, workout DVD's and in some cases, personal trainers; drawing (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: JEFF BOWMAN'S five-day-a-week exercise regimen includes half an hour on a treadmill followed by 60 minutes on his gym's weight machines. But when he travels, his workout routine is interrupted not only by his itinerary but also by the fitness habits of other hotel guests. ''Sometimes when I try to use the workout room at a hotel, there's a group of people down there using the equipment I had wanted, like the treadmill or the bicycle,'' said Mr. Bowman, who is an administrator for a custom publishing company in Laguna Hills, Calif. ''It's gotten to the point where I really don't want to use the fitness facilities anymore. It's just not worth the hassle.''
docs.snippet: Hotels are expanding their fitness offerings beyond their workout rooms, offering room-service delivery of fitness equipment, exercise manuals, workout DVD's and, in some cases, they'll send a personal trainer to your room....

headline.main: Rooms, Yes. But Don't Expect Service.

docs.abstract: Some hotels in New Orleans have managed to stay open with limited amenities and barebones staff since Hurricane Katrina hit on Aug 29; guests include government officials, firefighters and police officers, health care workers insurance agents and media; some are staying at reduced rates or at no charge; most hotels in city are closed; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Despite an exodus by hundreds of thousands of residents, and attempts to forcibly remove those remaining behind, New Orleans is no ghost town. At the Royal Sonesta Hotel on Bourbon Street, a small line formed at the front desk on Sunday. One man, wallet splayed on a handsome wooden counter, was paying for his stay. Another waited, only to be told by the hotel's general manager, Hans U. Wandfluh, that there were no rooms available.
docs.snippet: Some hoteliers have helped keep hotels open for rescue workers, and now the hotels could serve as a foundation for rebuilding the city....

headline.main: 'Three Hotels' on Stage in Croton Falls

docs.abstract: Alvin Klein reviews production of John Robin Baitz's two-character play Three Hotels at Schoolhouse Theater, Croton Falls, NY, starring and directed by Elizabeth D'Ottavio and Louise Gerber; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: RESOLVED to demonstrate that a life in the theater does not preclude having a life, Elizabeth D'Ottavio and Bram Lewis, actor, director, teacher and prime mover of the Phoenix Theater for almost a decade in Dobbs Ferry, then in Purchase, have one week to go, in John Robin Baitz's two-character play ''Three Hotels'' at the Schoolhouse here. Leave it to Lee Pope, in charge of the Schoolhouse and ever the woman who rearranges things, to find -- or better yet, to create -- a slot in her new theater series under an Actors' Equity contract, to provide the space for Ms. D'Ottavio and Mr. Lewis, her ''partner in life,'' as she calls him in the program. They live in Croton-on-Hudson with their 13-month-old daughter, Kaili.

headline.main: Right-Wing Hoteliers in Japan Anger China With Radical Historical Views
